content.description:
FA Matthew Peck/Dave MacFadden. Link several ice sections together up a long slope.  Must have had a mountaineering vibe that day. 



about 20m upriver of GFK.  

Standard Ice Rack.

FA Matthew Peck/ Dave MacFadden. Hook rock edges on the right to gain the ice in the tree.  Typically the first few moves are thin and dicey until you gain the thicker ice above. An unusual and delicate climb. 



Just upstream of Protect Ya Neck, this climb follows a frozen tree and is typically quite poorly iced at its base.  

Thin Ice Rack

There's a lot going on in such a short route!   Head up the steep ice to a ledge (bolt) then traverse the ledge (yikes) and gain the alcove (bolt) before climbing around onto the dangler and up a short vertical to finish (tree). 



From the main area, head to the right side of the main flow and left of the obvious large dangler.

Small to med Ice screws.  Bolts (2).

An Access gulley to get to the top of GFK.  No merit otherwise.  Here strictly for directions.



Short gulley located opposite the Dojo wall, currently the furthest south "climb" in the area.  Provides access to Ghost Face Killah, which is just upstream. 

Next to nothing.

FA Derek Eisses/Matthew Peck  Head up the steepening ice to the steep pillar to finish, choose the corner (easier) or straight up the front for spice. 



Middle line of the main wall.

Standard Ice Rack

The fun way out.  Typically solo'd to leave at the end of the day, but steeper than it looks. 



Ice Slab on the nearside of the Main Wall area.  Typically used to leave at the end of the day if you want a little bit more ice. 

Solo or Standard Ice Rack

FA Dave MacFadden/Matthew Peck. About 1km upstream of the main area and around a bend in the river you'll find this malty beauty weaving through the trees.  Typically shattery and thick, wander through the trees upward till the ice runs out. 



Head up river 1km around a bend.  On the far side of the river.

Standard Ice Rack

Easy Climbing with a final steep step, curling around the left side of the face.  Ideal for new leaders or setting anchors on the main wall. 



Leftmost low angled ice on the main wall

Standard Ice rack.

Short and steep!  Head up the obvious yellow flow, watch out for sunbake.



Dojo wall, downstream on the near shore.  Across from GFK.

Standard Ice Rack

Discovered in 2021 by Derek Eisses after examining the winter version of an old Summer watering hole, 36 Chambers (inspired by the Wu-Tang album, as are most of the climbs) is a small crag featuring characteristically short climbs for the area (ie Folly). Climbs here tend to be steeper than Folly, making it an excellent place for new leaders to improve their craft. Most of the climbs require the river to be frozen in order to climb here, though rock hopping is an option. Another sector about 1km upriver yields a few further climbs.
